sp.p: How? why is this the design? this clearly alters the Popes Ecclesiastical Government, and sets up a new Model. These mens Politicks will not only destroy both your Master and themselves, but all that have to do with 'em. For according to their Morals, no Prince in the world can ever be safe that corresponds with 'em.

sp.speaker: Monsieur.
sp.p: No, no, now you're as much out again the tother ways▪ pray let us hold to our business.

sp.speaker: Governour.
sp.p: Then pray satisfie me in this point; if England should break the Leagne with your Master, and Ally with Holland, &c.

sp.speaker: Monsieur.
sp.p: I'le tell ye, we have a reserve for that; for if we find England that way inclin'd, we have those which will u • dertake upon forfeiture of their Heads, to throw a bone between them, and soon set them together by the ears.

sp.speaker: Governour.
sp.p: How, what that way too? that would be fine work indeed, and i' •• Conscience feazable enough!

sp.speaker: Monsieur.
sp.p: 'Tis very certain, 'twill be done if we find our League with England strain'd; and I'le ingage they shall be continued so too, till my Masters work's done.

sp.speaker: Governour.
sp.p: How, will you engage for the continuance of a War? how can that be?

sp.speaker: Monsieur.
sp.p: Why there's a certain Bannocklander, who is said to have engag'd himself in the most sacred ties imaginable to serve my Master; and we are well assured of his care about Officers, and State-Ministers, so that in a short time,—

sp.speaker: Governor.
sp.p: In a short time, the Turk and your Master will subdue the whole world, and divide it between 'emselves.

sp.speaker: Monsieur.
sp.p: No, no, that's your mistake again.

sp.speaker: Governour.
sp.p: How then?

sp.speaker: Monsieur.
sp.p: Why my Master will have all or none: for though he may be constrained to use the Turk, yet you may be sure he'll give him Polyphemus's Law, devour him last, for he hates Compet • tors.

sp.speaker: Governour.
sp.p: But allowing a War between England and Holland, a • d all your Masters designs to take effect upon that, so as to give him the Conquest upon both, pray what must D. de P. be?

sp.speaker: Monsieur.
sp.p: My Masters Vice-Roy.

sp.speaker: Governour.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Monsieur.
sp.p: Here in these Kingdoms.—

sp.speaker: Governour.
sp.p: And is that all he makes this bustle for? for my part I cannot understand his politicks, for methinks it should be much better to be King, though of a limited Monarchy, then to be Vice-Roy to a King Absolute & Arbitrary.

sp.speaker: Monsieur.
sp.p: That's true, but D. de P. has so over-acted his part, that he cannot arrive at neither, without my Masters help.

sp.speaker: Governour.
sp.p: So that now it seems he must be contented with what your Master will give him.

sp.speaker: Monsieur.
sp.p: Give him! no no, 'tis supposed to be his own choice, as having declar'd, He would rather become a Vice-Roy to a Forreign power, though the greatest Tyrant on Earth, than truckle to such who ought to be his Slaves and Vassals.

sp.speaker: Governour.
sp.p: My thinks, 'tis impossible he should speak such words.

sp.speaker: Monsieur.
sp.p: 'Tis so reported, by those that pretend to know much.

sp.speaker: Governour.
sp.p: Then I have been doing fine things indeed, who have • ct • d as for my own life to advance his Interest, which as you say, now proves to be your Masters.

sp.speaker: Monsieur.
sp.p: Ay, but 'tis now too late to be sorry for that.

sp.speaker: Governour.
sp.p: Is it so? well then over boots over shooes; I'le rather choose to die honourably, than live basely.

sp.speaker: Monsieur.
sp.p: Why that's well resolved; 'tis Meritorious, and you dye in the Service of the Church.

sp.speaker: Governour.
sp.p: Then 'tis a bargain, but you told me I should have an account of your Masters principal friend.

sp.speaker: Monsieur.
sp.p: You shall know those in due time; I have better considered of that, and therefore desire to be excused till our next Meeting. Adieu Monsieur le Governour, Adieu.
